pull.title: test: Run rpc_txoutproof.py even with wallet disabled
pull.body:
Run the consensus test even when the wallet was not compiled. Also:

* Minor bugfix in MiniWallet
* Two new test cases (one cherry-picked from #19847)

test: MiniWallet: Default fee_rate in send_self_transfer, Pass in utxo_to_spend

Adds two new features to MiniWallet:

* The fee rate is irrelevant sometimes, so just set an arbitrary default
* The utxo to spend needs to be selected manually sometimes

issue.title: Tests are not triggered sometimes
issue.body:
Sometimes on a force-push, the tests are not triggered when they should have.


Example (only appveyor and travis run, not cirrus ci):

![Screenshot_2020-09-09 test Run rpc_txoutproof py even with wallet disabled by MarcoFalke · Pull Request #19922 · bitcoin bi](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6399679/92586166-31a2f200-f296-11ea-8913-d9b6e8d32860.png)


https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19922#event-3744887689

events.body: Force pushed to make travis python linter happy

issue.title: test: Convert non-wallet tests to use our python MiniWallet
issue.body:
It is possible to compile Bitcoin Core without the wallet. Though, many tests require the Bitcoin Core wallet to create and sign transactions. Ideally, every non-wallet test (for example consensus tests) are run even with the Bitcoin Core wallet disabled. This ensures that users running without the wallet can test their Bitcoin Core with the functional test suite.

Thus, tests that use the Bitcoin Core wallet should be rewritten to use the python MiniWallet.

This is an open-ended issue. You can find candidate tests via `git grep 'self.skip_if_no_wallet()'`. Exclude the tests that start with `wallet_`, as those are tests that are meant to test the Bitcoin Core wallet.

Refer to #19922 and #19800 as examples on how to approach this issue.

Edit: See also https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/20078#issuecomment-1106586728

#### Useful skills:

* Familiarity with the RPC interface
* Familiarity with our functional test suite
* Good python3 skills

#### Want to work on this issue?

For guidance on contributing, please read [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) before opening your pull request.

events.body: @MarcoFalke I realize that this is a merged PR, but I just had some hanging issues/comments regarding implementing `create_lots_of_big_transactions` while restructuring`mempool_limit.py`. My biggest concern is that wouldn't we need to change `send_self_transfer` to accommodate extra appends in the transaction outputs to make it large? or is there something i'm missing out? Any help is really appreciated
`send_self_transfer` only handles a single-in-single-out tx. If multi-in-multi-out txs are needed, it could make sense to add a new method for that.

> `send_self_transfer` only handles a single-in-single-out tx. If multi-in-multi-out txs are needed, it could make sense to add a new method for that.

Alright, I will open a PR soon with respected changes. Thank you :)
